basics.name: Jonathan Pool
basics.label: Developer of accessible web applications
basics.summary: I have developed web and database applications in JavaScript and other languages. I am currently adding accessibility features to existing applications and developing new ones that comply with international accessibility standards.

highlights: Developed PostgreSQL database of 3.1 billion lexical translations
Developed UIs and SEO for database

Director 2 summer internship programs with 45 interns

publications.name: Countering language attrition with PanLex and the Web of Data
publications.summary: Transformation of PanLex database to RDF, linkage with Lexvo and DBpedia, and publication as Linked Data; co-author with Patrick Westphas and Claus Stadler

publications.name: PanLex and LEXTRACT: Translating all Words of all Languages of the World
publications.publisher: Coling 2010: 23rd International Conference on Computational Linguistics
publications.summary: Research on expansion of coverage of PanLex, a lemmatic translation resource, via semi-automatic dictionary scraping; co-author with Timothy Baldwin and Susan M. Colowick

publications.name: Lemmatic Machine Translation
publications.summary: Panlingual Translator, a prototype lemmatic machine-translation system; co-author with Stephen Soderland, Christopher Lim, Mausam, Bo Qin, and Oren Etzioni

publications.name: Disambiguating for the Web: A Test of Two Methods
publications.publisher: K-CAP 2007: Fourth International Conference on Knowledge Capture
publications.summary: Paraphrasal disambiguation was more effective than truth-conditional disambiguation in an experiment with 386 subjects; co-author with Susan M. Colowick

publications.name: “The Official Language Problem
publications.summary: Proves in a mathematical model that it is possible to discover a fair and efficient policy on official languages even when language groups are willing to misrepresent the costs they would incur to use a nonnative official language

publications.name: The Distribution of Foreign Language Skills as a Game Equilibrium
publications.publisher: Game Equilibrium Models, ed. Reinhard Selten, vol. 4, Social and Political Interaction (Berlin: Springer)
publications.summary: Proofs of relationships among learning aptitude, language difficulty, and personal benefit in a game model, suggesting that those who learn the hardest languages get the most profit; co-author with Reinhard Selten
